segments.text: I didn't make the entire operation on about the seventh or eighth day.
I was with a patrol that had gone out to try to establish contact with the point elements of the enemy division to see exactly where they were.
We knew we were close, but we didn't exactly know
where their strength was.
A lot of patrols were being sent out.
The patrol I was with, I wasn't in charge.
A second lieutenant was in charge.
I was the assistant patrol leader.
At that time, I was a platoon sergeant.
We ran into an enemy patrol that just so happened by misfortune to be coming south while we were going north.
The point groups of each patrol exchanged fire.
They had a larger patrol than we did, and they rapidly gained fire superiority.
We started shooting from the hip, falling back.
We got disoriented, and we got separated because of the terrain.
Very thick undergrowth.
It was a high canopy of jungle overhead.
There was a lot of smoke.
There was a lot of dust.
There was mortar fire coming in.
I was backing up, shooting from the hip.
And my magazine made that particular noise it does, or my rifle, when you hit an empty magazine.
And it was pretty quick, the empty one, when you were in that situation.
I was trying to change magazines, but still backing up.
And somehow I stepped out into space, stepped over a creek bank, fell about eight or nine feet down to some rocks below.
being scared and having bit off more than we could chew.
And it looked like, from what we could tell at that time, we'd run into a whole battalion.
I don't think it was really that big, but it felt like it.
The fire was that heavy.
I was separated at that point from anybody else in the patrol.
There was no other Americans around.
I was moving down this creek.
It was pretty shallow, about ankle-deep water, a lot of rocks, overhanging vines.
Finally, I ran into two more guys that were crouched in the creek bed, and we started going back together.
The lieutenant had been killed outright.
Most of the first squad had been pretty well taken out.
We grouped up with some others.
There were a couple of wounded men.
We started carrying them.
All told, it was about nine or 10 of us.
We worked our way back into our lines.
Being that I was the assistant patrol leader, I gave the report as to what we had seen.
And I gave my estimation as to what the enemy strength was.
And I identified on the map as to where we met contact.
And that was really all I could do, as close as I could tell, which is pretty confusing.
By this time, the battalion area was coming under fire.
Mortar fire, 120-millimeter Russian rockets was coming in.
The battalion commander told me, it was a good report, I guess it was, he said that I needed to get over to BAS and get my leg tended to.
It was only then that I noticed that from my knee down, see that scar there?
I took a piece of shrapnel, it worked its way in along that bone and worked up under my knee.
And I had my whole combat boot and my whole lower leg was solid blood.
And I hadn't even realized that I thought I was wet because of the creek, which I'd been walking in.
And so as soon as that evening, right before it got dark, they medevaced me out.
They put a tag on me.
And I wasn't considered bad off to get immediate evacuation.
I went out with a second group of evacuees.
They took me back to a field hospital that was set up at Dong Ha.
And then they gave me sodium pentothal there.
I was more tired than I was hurt, because we'd been on our feet for days.
And then I was put into a C-123, flying boxcar-type aircraft.
It had racks, stretchers along both sides.
And they gave me salt water intravenously because of the
Dehydration.
We'd been without water, and it was real hot anyway, and then with the fire they'd set that we'd been fighting for days, too.
It was just extreme heat.
We'd lost a lot of men, too.
Sunstroke, heat exhaustion.
And I kind of passed out.
I don't remember what happened, but I came to, and I was at Da Nang General Hospital back in the rear.
And I spent three days there, and then they...
sent me by helicopter out to the hospital ship repose.
And I recuperated out there for a period of time, which I thoroughly enjoyed.
They had nurses there, and they had milkshakes, and it was great.
I hated to leave.
The outfit, in the meantime, had gone ahead and blunted the attack of the North Vietnamese Division.
By the time I got back, I got back in time.
When I rejoined my outfit, I was walking with a cane.
And I was considered a part of the sick, lame, and lazy, is what they called them.
were excused from full duty.
We had received a bunch of replacements and about 300 men to the battalion, but the battalion was still out in the field.
So being one of the senior NCOs that was at that time in the rear, I found billets for these people and tried to get weapons issued to them.
People that came over, replacements didn't come with rifles.
We issued them rifles in country.
We issued all their equipment right there.
They were raw.
Most of them had no more than eight weeks training.
All of them.
The highest ranking person there was a lance corporal that had been in the service maybe six months.
Most of them were right out of boot camp.
I also had the duty of having to identify the dead from the battalion because we'd taken a lot of casualties on this operation.
So I had to go up to the body bag area.
I saw my best friend.
That got me kind of shook up.
We was opening up the body bags and
A guy that I'd been in boot camp with, and served two tours of duty in Vietnam with, and been to Okinawa with, and across the water with.
In fact, he had been to my home several times.
Good friend.
It was really a shock to identify these bodies.
It was most of my outfit, it seemed like at the time.
I remember walking away from there.
I was so shook up.
I think I was even crying.
To tell you the truth, it sounds bad.
It didn't sound bad.
It was pretty rough.

When you have people that you know that you've cut up with and laughed with and joked with and worked with, and suddenly you're opening up little green bags and looking at them and saying, this is so-and-so and that's so-and-so.
But they had to have a positive idea on everybody.
We all wore dog tags, but...
Many times the dog tags weren't on for somebody when they found them for various reasons.
And then a lot of times some of us took our dog tags off when we went out on night patrols because they jingled.
And we didn't want anything to make a noise.
So there was a lot of reasons, but everybody didn't have a dog tag.
So we had to go by where we could identify them by somebody that knew them.
Sometimes you couldn't even do that.
After Operation Hastings, I...
wrangled with a battalion sergeant major five days R&R in Bangkok, which I thoroughly enjoyed.
And I won't go into that, but... Prostitutes, booze, and bras, huh?
Well, it was a... Don't worry, your wife won't hear this.
It was a great relief from where I'd been.
And the people in Thailand made us feel very welcome.
I say that, that I will always be indebted to the Thai people.
They treated us so kind.
Their kindness was just unbelievable.
Even when we didn't have money, they still treated us kind, which was very unusual.
Most American GIs had learned when the money runs out, the kindness runs out.
But I have to say, as a tribute to those people, to my dying day, I'll remember the Thai people for their kindness.
Of course, they were concerned about the Vietnamese coming into Thailand, and they very much are pro-American in Thailand.
It's one of our staunch allies there.
My uncle flew out of Thailand.
His base is in Thailand.
He flew across Cambodia and Laos and bombed.
Thailand is a country I will always admire, and someday, if I have a chance, I'll go back to Bangkok and take my family, because it's a...
It's a kind city, and at that time, it was made up of kind people.
I remember that.
I was given free meals.
I was given free liquor.
I won't go into all the things that was free in Thailand, but it was a nice place.
It was five days of relief.
And it was like going from hell to heaven, the comparison.
But then I had to go back to Vietnam.
I remember the day came, and the hotel people came around and woke us all up that was there.
They did it with the greatest kindness.
They said they were really sorry to tell us, but we had to leave.
And our time was up.
The plane was waiting for us.
So we went back to Vietnam.
And I got back and was returned to full duty, naturally, in time for a, I think, right after I got back, I was on a Sparrowhawk mission in North Vietnam.
It was an unsuccessful one.
We went in to pick up a downed pilot, but the enemy had already got him.
We found the crash site of the F4.
We destroyed anything of importance militarily on the craft that we could.
And we radioed for pickup.
We pulled back out of there again.
After that, spent a little bit of time around
Camelot fortifying it, digging holes, long bunkers, filling sandbags, laying concertina wire.
And there was a lot of this kind of working parties in between time.
Any time that we weren't actively engaged with the enemy, we were filling sandbags, digging holes, laying concertina, putting out minefields, or something like that.
They always had work for you.
It never ended.
But we'd grown used to that.
That was life.
That's what life was then.
We had Operation Deckhouse 4.
I always remember Deckhouse 4 as a real screw-up operation.
They formed up the 26th Marines, which is another regiment, and it was going to become part of the 4th Marine Division, which I'm not sure was ever really truly activated.
The 26th Marines was the first regiment of the 4th Marine Division to be activated since World War II.
They'd had them then.
26 was made up of replacements of cooks, bakers, Remington Raiders.
That's typist.
Anybody and everybody they could put together to form a regiment of Marines.
Uh, we were to operate with the 26th Marines by we, I mean what was left of the fourth Marines at this time.
And we were pretty dismal.
We didn't look like a regular Marine regiment.
We were few in number.
We were dirty.
We had torn uniforms.
We were suntan to the degree.
Every person in my outfit had a 28-inch waist because there was no fat on us.
We had marched the length of Vietnam at least twice.
We looked more like a gang of pirates than we did Marines.
But the 26th had fresh uniforms, fresh combat boots, fresh helmets.
Their helmet covers were newly camouflaged.
They had the latest in equipment.
A lot of our M14s were so banged around.
Some of us at that time still had M14s.
Some had M16s.
They were phasing them out by then.
You mentioned you despise the M16.
I don't like the M16.
We call it the Mattel toy.
They always show it in the pictures you see at Vietnam.
They show that's the only weapon that was there was the M16.
But the M14 did a lot of fighting over there, and a lot of the outfits never had anything but M14s.
I have a Mini.
A Mini 14?
Mm-hmm.
I like the M14.
It was a good solid weapon, and it was the last of the American-issue weapons that had a real solid wooden stock.
It had a good bayonet.
It was heavy enough that if you did get into hand-to-hand combat, which I was only in one time in the whole time, but we did have one time, that you could fight with something.
The M16 fires faster.
It has a higher muzzle velocity.
The cyclic rate of fire is greater, but it's...
It tends to jam more.
That's my experience.
I never had an M14 jam with me as many times as an M16 would.
If you went on an operation with an M16, you knew it was going to jam on you.
It was going to jam.
It was just a matter of when.
No matter how much you tried to keep it clean, and we cleaned them every opportunity we get.
We cleaned our magazines.
We even cleaned the ammunition individually, round by round, to keep every bit of grain of sand off it.
Because a grain of sand caught between the sides of the spring in a magazine would jam it.
And instead of your ammo feeding up by the spring pressure, it would get caught.
And if we would fire around, there wouldn't be anything there.
because the other one was stuck down in the magazine.
Then you'd have to field strip a weapon, pull out a magazine, pull out the ammunition, pull out the spring, clean it.
And this is a rough thing to do in the middle of a battle.
People get killed that way.
The M16 got a lot of good men killed.
But that's another story.
I won't get off on that.
Anyway, getting back to this Operation Deckhouse 4, the 26 Marines were moving forward.
in full regimental strength.
We were on their flanks.
We were there mainly as guides because we were combat veterans and we knew the terrain.
The 26th was supposed to bear the brunt of the fighting.
We were understrength.
We were sick.

We were suffering from malaria and dysentery, and we weren't supposed to do anything more than provide guides for them to go in to, again, once again, come up against the 242nd B Division of the North Vietnamese Army.
We seemed to always be fighting them.
Wherever we went, they were there.
Well, they ran into them.
The North Vietnamese were regulars.
They were seasoned veterans.
They'd fought many a Marine by this time.
They knew all the tricks of the trade.
They laid down a heavy barrage of 120 millimeter Russian rockets on the 26 Marines.
And the regiment, who had never been tested in battle before, they didn't phase them in gradually.
They just threw them into a major battle.
They ran.
You won't find that in the history books or you won't see it on TV, but the 26th Marines ran.
Half of them threw down their rifles and ran.
It was to the rear march with track shoes.
It wasn't an organized retreat.
It was en route.
They threw the 4th Marines in between what was left of the 4th Marines, in between the retreat of the 26th Marines and the advance of an enemy division.
That was the end of the 4th Marine Regiment in Vietnam for all practical purposes.
We stopped the advance of an enemy division.
We were an understrength regiment.
We were a regiment of about 1,500 men.
They threw us against 20,000 regulars.
North Vietnamese Division, roughly 20,000 men.
And they wiped you out?
They pretty well wiped us out.
E Company, 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines, three days later had 17 men left in the company out of a line company of 208 officers and men.
Someone told me that you were in a combat situation where the only way you survived was having dead bodies piled on top of you.
Was this the situation?
That was the situation.
We were in a little area.
As the troops were moving, you got to understand the interplay of large bodies of troops, battalions, companies.
My company went into an area.
We were trying to, this was a multiple day operation.
It wasn't something that happened in an afternoon.
It was over a period of several days.
The 26th was falling back on the coast.
We were trying to cover it.
We were falling back, but slower.
Trying to lay down protective fire, fall back, stop them with fire, call in artillery, airstrikes, fall back.
It was kind of a leapfrog type thing.
We were allowing the 26th what was... Actually, they didn't take that many casualties.
They didn't stay around to take casualties.
As you can tell by the tone of my voice, I don't have very much use for the 26th Marines.
But...
Anyway, someone decided that we needed an enemy prisoner.
My company commander at this time was a new man.
He had been sent over to us from a motor transport outfit.
He didn't have any infantry experience.
He had very little combat experience.
But he was a captain, and they needed a captain.
And he filled the bill at the time.
His mission was to capture a prisoner and get him back to battalion for questioning.
And we got sucked into an ambush.
A North Vietnamese regular came out, fired at us, and ran back down the hill.
The captain ordered a platoon, first platoon of our company, to go send a squad to get this man.
Everyone advised against it, but he was the captain and he ordered it.
So the squad went.
The squad was pretty well wiped out in seconds by grazing fire from surrounding hills.
Instead of taking his losses and falling back and calling in heavier weapons, he sent in the rest of the first platoon to try to get the survivors of the first squad out.
The first platoon was chewed up in the meat grinder.
Again, we begged him to fall back, call in heavy weapons.
There's no use killing more men, but he sent in the other two platoons of the rifle company to try to get out the first platoon.
He was at this point in tears.
He got so many men killed.
He couldn't think of anything except he had made a blunder, a mistake, and he was trying to pull it out some way.
So the other two platoons, second and third platoon, weapons platoon was attached at this time to the various rifle platoons we went into.
My own feeling was we were walking into it.
I knew it.
I felt it.
I really wasn't all that scared.
I guess I'd accepted that I was going to die.
That was just all there is to it, because that was what was going to happen.
I'd been in combat too long.
You become a realist after a while.
The human body doesn't stand up against too much flying metal.
And we got hit, naturally.
We expected it.
We did.
The heavy weapons that had chewed up the rest of our company got us, too.
The captain was hit.
People were yelling for Corman.
They were shooting everywhere.
There was smoke.
There was dirt.
People were falling.
People were screaming.
Somebody, I don't remember who right now, he wasn't in my platoon, fell on me.
He was a heavy guy.
I think his name was Edwards.
Fell as in dead?
Yeah, fell as in dead.
He fell on me, and blood was all over me.
I had just emptied my magazine.
I had an empty magazine.
And I was in the process of changing magazines, switching.
We had magazines taped to magazines for quick change.
And I was trying to switch it around when he fell on me.
I fell down the grass.
He was on top of me.
And about that time, the shooting stopped.
There was a couple of pops, a few more pops.
And then there was nothing.
It was just quiet.
You could smell the carbide and the smoke.
And as always, the flies was already buzzing around.
I just laid there thinking I was the only one left alive because there was no resistance.
The company had been...
I'm sorry.
We had been ambushed, effectively ambushed.
The fire had discontinued.
Yeah, the fire had discontinued.
It was quiet.
And I was covered in blood, not my own.
And the enemy soldiers, North Vietnamese regulars, were walking around.
I could see their feet.
I didn't dare raise my head.
I didn't even move.
I tried to suppress my breathing.
They were taking rings and watches off of my friends and my buddies.
They were laughing.
They'd wiped out a Marine company.
I felt pretty good about it, I guess.
As it turned out, there were more of us than just myself.
Half a squad had managed to pull back up the hill before they got sucked in the valley, and they were up there
There were a few others that were wounded that managed to fake that they were dead.
There were some that were wounded that were killed during this period of time.
I heard they shot them or they bayoneted them.
More often than not, they bayoneted them, no use wasting a bullet.
It was a long night.
I sat there.
As luck would have it, I fell into an ant bed.
But I didn't move.
The ants were crawling all over me and biting the hell out of me.
And I guess I had all kinds of thoughts that night.
I even considered suicide rather than become a North Vietnamese prisoner.
They didn't treat Marines too good, at least that's what we had heard.
But I was afraid to move.
I was cramped, too.
I had a cramp in my leg.
It sounds kind of looking back on it now 20 something years ago It sounds
Probably for civilized society, pretty gross, I guess.
But that's the way it was.
I was a sergeant.
I was a platoon sergeant.
I was scared.
I felt alone.
I was hurting.
I was cramping.
But I didn't dare move.
I didn't dare massage the cramp, which you feel instinctively you've got to do.
I could hear the enemy.
They were not that far away.
I could hear them talking.
In Vietnamese, I guess my fear was greater than my suffering.
At that point, at least it controlled everything else.
It's the kind of situation, and what I mean by gross is you don't even move when you go to the bathroom.
You just go.
It's pretty gross, I admit that.
War is gross, and that was about the grossest part I'd been involved in up to that point.
You hadn't received any actual war?
I wasn't sure, to tell you the truth, at that point.
I wasn't sure that I wasn't wounded.
I was hurt.
I was cramped.
I was in an awkward position.
I was covered in blood, and I had, when you're scared, your adrenaline flows.
I can look back on it educated now.
And your adrenaline conceals a multitude of sins.
You don't know whether you're wounded, and I'd been wounded before and not known it.
I wasn't sure.
I didn't think I was.
But I wasn't honestly sure one way or the other.
We were tired anyway, which was so...
I guess I slept off a known part of the night.
Catnapped, more than anything.
Every time a twig broke, I'd wake up.
I heard some whispering.
But I wasn't sure.
I thought it was American...
But I wasn't sure, and I was afraid.
And there was somebody calling for water.
I kept hearing somebody call for water.
I was sure of that.
In my mind, I was sure of it, but I was afraid it might be a trick, too, to see if there was anybody else that they could get.
We were in elephant grass.
Elephant grass is like, the closest thing in Texas to it is Johnson grass.
It grows taller, though, and it's thicker bladed, and it cuts you the same as Johnson grass.
And we'd fallen down in this stuff.
That was what the bottom of this valley was, filled with it.
So there was a goodly number of us that were sort of concealed by the grass.
Even though we were close, you couldn't see.
I couldn't see anyway.
It was dark.
I could hear things.
And of course the mosquitoes were having a field day on us, all of us.
I was afraid of tigers.
I kept thinking about tigers because tigers were in that area and they liked to feed on dead bodies.
For some reason, that was my greatest fear, was a big tiger coming down and grabbing me.

uh i kept visualizing it every time i heard a sound i would think that the tiger was tiger was coming we had seen them before tigers actually stuck around well they love to feed them yeah they love to feed on the on the bodies after a battle happened a number of times um of course
No tigers showed up, obviously.
I guess there was too much activity around, human activity.
They usually go to a battlefield where there was bodies and there was nobody around.
We'd find their evidence later many times.
The next day, the battle picked up again early in the morning before daylight.
A lot of artillery fire.
I didn't know whose it was.
Some planes passed overhead.
There was some rocket fire, heavy weapons fire, light weapons fire.
I didn't know who was firing at whom.
I just continued to lie there.
Around noon, maybe a little later, I'm not sure, the weapons fire picked up pretty heavy, and it was around the edge of the valley, I could tell, coming down from the hills.
Sometime that afternoon, Fox Company, sister company of ours in the same battalion, came in, and they took a few casualties, quite a few, I think, and they started pulling bodies out.
And when I realized that our people was there, of course, I called.
And I was so cramped I couldn't walk because I'd stayed in a cramped position all night long, not moving.
And I thought I was wounded at the time.
It turned out that I wasn't.
All told, there was 17 men that came out of the company, including a portion of the squad that had got away up on the hill.
And that was the biggest portion of the men that was left alive out of E Company.
All of us were evacuated.
The battalion commander ordered every single man in E Company evacuated.
There were several put up for medals after that.
It was put up for a bronze star.
It never came through.
There was no witness, which any kind of a citation has to be accompanied by a witness.
There was no living witness anyway.
After that, our battalion was sent to Okinawa.
That was several weeks later, two or three weeks.
We went back to Fubai.
They let us rest up for a while, and then they decided that we were no longer combat effective.
We were too weak materially.
We lost a lot of weapons.
We lost a lot of men.
Rather than send the replacements to us, they sent them to other outfits.
They sent us back to Okinawa for reorganization and re-equipping.
That was my last major operation in Vietnam.
Well, that was Deck House 4, that particular operation, the end of Deck House 4.
Hastings came, but Hastings and Deck House 4 ran into each other.
Where one ended, the other began.
We pulled, and our initial contact with the North Vietnamese on Hastings became like a stalemate.

We had fought each other down to a standstill, and that's when they threw the 26 Marines in to try to post-corrupt the attack, and that's when the 26 Marines was routed, and we were thrown in to protect them.
And then we were chewed up.
In the process, however, we did manage, the battalion that I was in managed to inflict very heavy casualties on the enemy.
They didn't get everything for nothing either.
And they pulled back into North Vietnam.
It blunted their attack totally.
And that was our goal.
So I guess to that degree, we were successful.
Later after that, there were, of course, a lot more operations.
I was sent back to Okinawa, then sent on back to the States, and then I got my separation from active duty.
I'd spent all total 22 months in Vietnam, two tours of duty.
I had a total of 13 major combat operations.
I don't know how many patrols or minor skirmishes.
Our battalion captured, killed,
I think the numbers was reported something in the neighborhood of 4,000 enemy troops from our battalion.
We all together as a battalion, 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines at that time had the highest casualty rate of any American combat command.
But we had also the highest prisoner rate and the highest kill rate of any American combat command.
We saw more action from the beginning
until the time that they pulled us out than any other combat command.
So forces eliminated Vietnam and the 4th Marines?
No, they regrouped.
They reorganized it.
They sent it back in with new men, new equipment, new material.
The 4th Marines is still active today.
The 4th Marines, during World War II, the 4th Marines was again made up of the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd Battalions.
The 1st and 3rd Battalions was surrendered immediately
at Corregidor by General Wainwright.
The 2nd Battalion at that time was not on the Philippines.
They were on detached duty to some other part of the Pacific.
They were not surrendered at Corregidor.
They were detached.
They had no regiment to belong to.
The regimental colors of the 4th Marine Regiment was nonexistent until Operation Starlight.
We won our regimental colors back on Operation Starlight.
We were awarded colors again for the first time.
All of those years in between Corregidor and Operation Starlight, the 4th Marine Regiment had no regimental colors because they'd been surrendered to the Japanese.
The only American combat command that could surrender colors, the rest were remnants of command at Corregidor, was the two battalions of the 4th Marine Regiment, which was under an army general.
The 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines during World War II, became what was known as a Raider Battalion.
They were the ones that took Macon Island.
during the Pacific.
The 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines were designated as Marine Raiders.
They still told that, or at least when I was in that title to the date, they were the 2nd Marine Raider Battalion assigned to the 4th Marine Regiment.
So you have a big history with the 4th Marines.
The 4th Marines used to be known as the China Marines.
If you ever heard of the Boxer Rebellion, the Marines that was stationed in Peking, that was a unit of the Fourth Marines, the China Marines.
I saw the movie.
That was the units of the Fourth Marines.
When you got back to America, what were your reactions?
I mean, people, how they treated you.
I didn't like it.
I was sent to Okinawa first.
In Okinawa, we were given a thorough physical examination to make sure we weren't carrying any unwanted bugs back to the States.
We were given new uniforms.
Are you going to want to pay for that, or would you like to keep it on the tab?
I'll pay for it.
Okay, sure.
They didn't do very much in the way of what you would call orientation training or anything like that.
I was at that point in time, as were the other people with me, we were nothing but combat Marines.
That's all I was.
That's all I had learned.
My life before then had been totally subverted.
When I looked at a tree, I saw a possible place for a sniper.
When I looked at a bush, if it was big enough to conceal a man, I saw a possible place for a sniper.
When I saw a door after the fighting, the in-house fighting in the way,
Remember, we learned then to go in by tossing grenades before you walked in a building.
Because if the North Vietnamese proved to be quite capable and willing to shoot, and even knowing they would be killed, they would take somebody with them.
So we cleared a room by grenade.
But you've learned these things.
What I'm trying to say is, when I came back to the so-called civilization, it was quite a shock for me.
And as I'm sure as it was for everybody else, it was very difficult.
The government didn't provide any kind of...

uh phase out uh returning you to civilization we went from okinawa i was put on a troop ship a usns ship it sent to uh yokohama japan where we changed ship went on another type of a ship it was a government ship but it was a larger one to san francisco and it was
27 days across the Pacific, I believe, into San Francisco.
We came under the Golden Gate.
Golden Gate looked beautiful.
Hadn't been home in a long time.
There were on that ship hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of armed forces personnel, Army, Air Force, Marine, Naval.
Most had been from Vietnam.
They had given us fresh uniforms, but we were still very tan.
We were still very skinny.
We were still very much...
We hadn't been out of Vietnam that long.
We were still very much combat people, all of us.
We were stopped in the San Francisco Bay.
On one side was Oakland.
On the other side was San Francisco.
We could see the lights of both cities in the evening, but the ship was at anchor, and we didn't know why.
It stayed at anchor out there for three days.
Then they took us to the Army docks, I believe it was, for debarkation.
We went off, and then they trucked us

all the way around and we came back in through the gates onto treasure island where once again we were given medical examinations but on getting into treasure island there was some kind of a protest although they the government and the san francisco police didn't allow the protesters to get real close we could see them at a distance it was looked to be like young people uh young men and women that were yelling and and uh shouting and there was a lot of them we went into the
the Treasure Island Naval Depot there.
And they kept us there for a period of time.
They brought our shot records up to date, which most of us were inspired.
Why, I don't know, but they did.
They checked us over again.
It was our third physical, I think, something like that, making sure we weren't carrying any bugs again.
And then they let us go.
They let us go home in groups.
They wouldn't let a whole group of us go out together.
We had to have transportation to either the
airport or the bus station or wherever we were going by what means.
And we were not allowed a lot of liberty in San Francisco.
None of us could go into San Francisco.
The city of San Francisco requested that we not have any liberty.
So we were let out in groups of seven or eight.
I went by plane to Los Angeles International.
My parents picked me up there and I was given
I want to say 20 days leave, and then I had to report to El Toro, and it was only for a period of waiting around for discharge, that's all.
But I had to stay in the government and make roll call each morning and didn't do nothing there but drank beer and make formations to say that I was still there.
That gave me another physical.
Checked my teeth, which was terrible.
I think I had something like nine fillings I had to get.
Yeah.
When you don't brush your teeth for a long time, that sort of thing sort of happens.
We didn't have toothbrushes in Vietnam.
So it's really just like living like an animal.
Well, I guess by certainly by the standards that we are accustomed to right now or before it was.
Do you think now after you came back and you learned all the crap that happened over there, do you think we could have won that war?
We could have won that war on any Friday.
Anytime we wanted to, we could have won the war.
1966, I believe it was, we had 700,000 men in Vietnam, American forces.
There was, if they had allowed us to cross the North Vietnamese border in force, a combined land-sea attack, amphibious operation, combined with probably a...
airborne operation and then a massive attack across the border, we could have taken North Vietnam.
But do you think the Chinese might?
That was the fear.
At least that's what we heard was the fear that if we had attacked North Vietnam, the Chinese would have become involved.
I can't answer that.
I don't know.
It would just be a speculation.
My guess would be as good as somebody else's.
But I know we could have taken North Vietnam.
I have no doubt about that.
we were not allowed to cross borders overtly.
We had to do it covertly.
When we went into what they called incursions into Laos or Cambodia or North Vietnam, it was done as a covert operation.
And that is to say we... Sparrowhawk-type operations, missions, to pick up downed pilots, or in some cases they were reconnaissance missions.
In some cases, we went in for reconnaissance purposes, not necessarily to do anything except, in some cases, we went in with a, you have two types of patrols.
You have a combat patrol or a recon patrol.
And some of those patrols were combat, to go in to destroy a bridge, to go in to blow up a SAM site.
Those were rare, really rare.
Only if they couldn't get it some other way, usually an airstrike could take them out.
I don't know if that answers your question, sir.
We talked about this earlier when I put the tape on pause, but could you give your impression of the argument of the South Vietnamese people as a whole towards America?
The South Vietnamese people as a whole, I think, looking back on it, were just kind of tired.
That's how they looked.
They looked like they were tired.
They were tired of war.
They were tired probably of governments that were not functioning the way they should.
I don't think they trusted us.
I think that some few individuals that we met from time to time and helped from time to time may have thought that some few of us were okay people.
I know that we had contact with some South Vietnamese and it was a good contact, but these were individuals meeting individuals.
I could equally say that I know on some occasions where we had contact and it was a negative contact because
We burned the village down.
We destroyed the rice fields.
We went in and took the rice that was stored in storage between seasons.
It was considered, if we found rice, as a possible stock for the enemy.
So we destroyed it.
The most simple way was to throw it into a river.
It would swell, become no good.
I know that in those cases that the enemy, by their looks, hated us.
I remember one morning on one operation, it was a search and destroy.
Search and destroy missions didn't usually have names like the big operations.
It was just a search and destroy.
They'd get you all up, form up a couple of companies, and they'd march you to a village, and you'd go through in line.

You'd round up all the people, bring them into the central village square or the center of the village, as the case may be, and then we would either arrange transport to haul them out to relocation centers
or move them by foot to some place where they could get vehicles to take them to relocation centers.
The Vietnamese were very much afraid of helicopters.
They didn't want to go on board them at all.
Even when they were wounded, they were afraid of them.
They didn't even particularly like getting on trucks.
When they would finally be forced on trucks, I think many of them thought they were being taken to their death.
Our relocation centers that we set up were designed

to clear areas for combat operations so that there would not be villagers in the way, so that we could lay down artillery fire, we could call in airstrikes without having civilians in the way, so to speak.

Of course, it's awfully hard to tell a person who's lived in a village for all their life and their parents lived there and their grandparents before them, and you could probably go back a few thousand years in some cases, that this is done for their benefit.

You can imagine the average American, if they're suddenly uprooted by foreign soldiers to come in at the point of bayonets, get you out of your bed and say you're being relocated for your own convenience, for your protection.
Most of our people would be somewhat upset.
Although, by comparison to our homes, their homes were back shots.
It was still their homes.
Very tight land.
Yes, they were.
They were a people, the South Vietnamese, that...
We're tired of war.
They've known war all their life, nothing but war.
I don't think that they welcomed us.
I don't think they particularly hated us, all of them.
Some of them did.
Some of them didn't.
Some of them, some Vietnamese girls married American GIs.
There was, I wouldn't even venture as a guess to what percentage that was, probably very low, but it was like people anywheres.
They were a people caught up in a giant,
It was a mess.
It was an interaction, a power struggle between different ideologies.
And they were the people that was caught in the middle.
I cannot fault them because of their lack of dedication to the war effort.
Looking at it, at the time being, I did.
I have to be honest.
At the time being, I thought they were a gutless bunch of creeps.
We came over there to help them.
And then in the middle of the battle, they turned off and run.
But looking back on it in retrospect,
It's awful hard, taking it from their point of view, to really hit them too hard, to criticize them too much.
We pulled out.
We left.
Most of those people stayed behind, and they had to face their conquerors then.
And I'm sure many of them, the ones that were the most loyal to us, the ones that were the most friendly to us, I'm sure they suffered.
I'm sure their neighbors told on them.
Went down the wrong way.
That's rough.
The Arvin, as a military force,
Yeah, second rate at best.
And that's a given.
That's being nice.
As long as we bolstered up their planks and bolstered up them, held them up, they could form the pretense of an effective fighting force.
The moment that we weren't there,

Defense crumbled so I could not honestly say the Arvin was anything to be respected as a military unit if that answers your question, I You were They had other things over there is equivalent to our National Guard.
They have what they call PS popular forces They were usually barefoot They carried no pack no helmet dressed in the typical village dress they would have a rifle a pouch and
Some ammunition.
Any number of things.
All kinds of weapons.
Communist weapons, American weapons, French weapons, anything and everything they could get.
P.S.
generally, we employed them in the beginning as scouts, as interpreters.
Some of them spoke English or broken English.
The most difficult thing we always had was interpretation, trying to talk to the people.
Americans are not bilingual.

even our officers are not and we're not then either i think we're okay thank you there was a goodly number of vietnamese who spoke french more so than spoke english in fact so most translations from vietnamese to french to english a lot of it occurred that way
There was some who spoke English, or at least a bit of English, and we would communicate by sign language and by drawings and pictures and everything else.
They tried to assign to most companies an interpreter.
The interpreters
We're pretty shaky.
They might be here today, it might be gone tomorrow, and you had to watch your C-rations and your watch and any personal effects you might have if they were around.
They would steal just as soon as not.
Do you think some of them were calm?
Oh, yeah.
Some of them were, there's no doubt about it.
Some were working for both sides, were opportunist.
I think that the...
We adopted a very casual, our officers are the people that was in command.
When we set up areas such as major defense areas like Da Nang, Dong Ho, Phu Bai, a lot of these places, they would allow the Vietnamese to come in and set up a trading market with the Americans.
They would sell things that we couldn't get through our normal supply system, mirrors for shaving, little pans to put water in instead of your hands.
